headline.main: Helping Unlicensed Chinese Contractors by Bridging the Language Gap
headline.print_headline: Helping Under-the-Table Chinese Contractors Get Right With the Law

docs.abstract: There are countless Chinese immigrant contractors performing home improvement projects without a city license, according to teachers preparing contractors to take the licensing test.
docs.snippet: There are countless Chinese immigrant contractors performing home improvement projects without a city license, according to teachers preparing contractors to take the licensing test.

byline.original: By COREY KILGANNON and JEFFREY E. SINGER

docs.lead_paragraph: If New York City's licensing test for home improvement contractors were given in Chinese and included the finer points of bamboo scaffolding, contractors like Gary Lin, 42, of Queens would breathe much easier taking it.

headline.main: Monday Reading: Winter Getaways for Every Age

docs.abstract: Winter getaways for every age, GPS devices let amateur snoops follow a car's trail, Vassar College has an "oops" admissions moment and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.
docs.snippet: Winter getaways for every age, GPS devices let amateur snoops follow a car's trail, Vassar College has an "oops" admissions moment and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

docs.lead_paragraph: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

docs.lead_paragraph: Many Catholic colleges are pushing back against a ruling by the Obama administration that the new health care law requires insurance plans at Catholic institutions to cover birth control.

headline.seo: Law Fuels Contraception Controversy on Catholic Campuses
headline.main: Ruling on Contraception Draws Battle Lines at Catholic Colleges
headline.print_headline: Ruling on Contraception Draws Battle Lines at Catholic Colleges

docs.abstract: Many Catholic colleges are pushing back against ruling by the Obama administration that the new health care law requires insurance plans at Catholic institutions to cover birth control; Catholic Church considers it morally wrong to prevent contraception by any artificial means; rule has now run headlong into a dispute over values as Republican presidential contenders compete for the most conservative voters (Series: Political Science).
docs.snippet: Many Catholic colleges are pushing back against a ruling by the Obama administration that the new health care law requires insurance plans at Catholic institutions to cover birth control.

docs.lead_paragraph: The new thinking has been dragged down by some old style budgetary inertia. Mr. Obama needs to push the Pentagon to do better.
docs.abstract: Editorial asserts that the $259 billion in budget cuts over the next five years announced by the Pentagon are a good first step, but are not nearly enough; outlines three areas where more cuts would make sense; asserts that the era of hard choices at the Pentagon has barely begun.
docs.snippet: The new thinking has been dragged down by some old style budgetary inertia. Mr. Obama needs to push the Pentagon to do better.

keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: The administration’s commitment to affordable birth control is welcome at a moment when women’s access to reproductive health care is under assault.
docs.abstract: Editorial applauds the Obama administration for its rejection of broad exemptions from a new rule requiring all health plans to cover birth control, without a deductible or co-payment, which were supported by Roman Catholic bishops and social conservatives; asserts that the administration's commitment to affordable birth control is welcome at a moment when women's access to reproductive health care is under assault in the courts, state legislatures and Congress, as well as on the Republican campaign trail.
docs.snippet: The administration’s commitment to affordable birth control is welcome at a moment when women’s access to reproductive health care is under assault.

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s superintendent of the new office has taken on high-profile issues, and some see it as infringing on Attorney General Eric T. Schneiderman’s territory.

headline.seo: Expanding Reach, Cuomo Creates Second Cop on Financial Beat
headline.main: Expanding Reach, Cuomo Creates Second Cop on Financial Beat
headline.print_headline: New Cop on the Financial Services Beat Expands His Reach, and Cuomo’s

docs.abstract: Benjamin M Lawsky has been carrying out duties normally associated with a state attorney general since becoming superintendent of New York State's Department of Financial Services, which became active in October; critics say office is Gov Andrew M Cuomo's attempt to infringe on territory of Atty Gen Eric T Schneiderman, while supporters say state needs the additional financial supervision.
docs.snippet: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s superintendent of the new office has taken on high-profile issues, and some see it as infringing on Attorney General Eric T. Schneiderman’s territory.
